Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Grant: Addressing the Need of STEM Retention at HSSU

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Harris-Stowe State University, a small HBCU in the St. Louis metropolitan area, serves approximately 2,000 students, ninety percent African American. Harris-Stow also has a legacy of preparing candidates for careers in elementary and secondary science and mathematics education.

The HBCU-UP project at Harris-Stowe has two main goals: to increase the academic achievement level for first year students in mathematics and science courses; and to increase the overall enrollment and graduation rates of students pursuing teacher degrees in mathematics and science.

The strategies proposed make up the Retention Enhancement Program (REP) and the Teacher Education Reform Program (TERP), and emerged as a result of a planning process supported by an NSF HBCU-UP planning grant. Many of the strategies parallel each other for the Retention Enhancement Program and the Teacher Education Reform Program. These strategies include student support services (e.g. peer tutoring and peer mentoring); curriculum reform in mathematics and science; enhancement and expansion of research opportunities for students, including pre-service teachers, and a residential summer academy for incoming students. The program will be supported by a Director of Retention for Mathematics and Science who will coordinate the retention and recruiting efforts.

Through the HBCU-UP project, Harris-Stowe State University expects an increase in the number of teacher education candidates in mathematics and science, and an increase in the retention of first year students in mathematics and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The HBCU-UP Implementation project seeks to fulfill the following objectives:

1.  To increase the academic achievement levels of first year students in mathematics and the sciences

2.  To increase overall enrollment and graduation rates in
STEM eduction degree programs

.  To reform the STEM curriculum at Harris-Stowe State University

4.  To develop an undergradute research program

As a result of the grant, Harris-Stowe added a summer academy for students majoring in math and sciences.  over the life of the grant, a total of 190 student participated in the five week porgram.  The success rate of students who participated in the summer academy was 98 percent.  Additionally, students who participated in this program had a higher retention rate than those who did not participate.

The number of students who majored in STEM went from 50 students in 2008 to 198 currently. In terms of degree production, 2 students graduated in 2008 to 19 in 2015.  In 2013, Harris-Stowe graduated five African-American graduates in math (a total of six graduated that year) and as a result, ranked number #1 in the state of Missouri out of 34 public and private institutions in degree production in math.  Additionally, Diverse Issues in Higher Education a national publication ranked Harris-Stowe #47 in the nation in graduating African-Americans in mathematics.

As part of STEM curriculum reform at Harris-Stowe, new degree progrograms and minors were added:

1. B.S. degree in Mathematics

2. B.S. degree in Biology

     Minor:  Pre-Medicine and Urban Ecology

3.  Substanibility and Urban Ecology

     Minor:  Computation, Physical Science, Chemistry, Biology

      Certificate:  Urban Agriculture

The grant called for at least 16 undergraduate research opportunitites for students over the life of the grant.  However, there were more than 70 undergraduate research projects.  Students presented their research at the Harris-Stowe Unidergraduate Research Symposium. Students also presented

at the AAAS/NSF undergraduate research conference (one student earned first place in Genomics category and another student earned 2nd place in the math category.  Students participated in the following undergraduate research programs and projects:

American Society of Cell Biology, Botganical Society of America, Argonne Science REsearch Laboratory, National Organization for Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and the Chemical Engineers Regional Conference.

Harris-Stowe has increased partnerships with STEM organizations including a 3+2/3 Math and Engineering partership with St. Louis University Parks College of Engineering.  Students who participate in this program will complete a math degree and an engineering degree within five years from both institutions.  Harris-Stowe signed a MOU with Kansas City University School of Medicine and BioSciences.  Students will earn a Master's dgree in Biosciences from KCUSB and a biology degree from Harris-Stowe.

Overall, the Implementation grant has transformed STEM at Harris-Stowe.  There is an excitement and energy throughout the institution. 


Last Modified: 11/28/2015
Modified by: Dwyane Smith
